commentBody: Hopefully,,I’ll be the first to comment on the Tuesday puzzle, almost 12 hours before the puzzle is set to drop. Seems this is a tough week for the wordplay column, but that seems to be a pretty regular occurrence in these parts. I can’t really comment on the puzzle yet, but will just add my thoughts in support of Lewis and his Asheville friends and neighbors, we all have you in our prayers.

Has anyone figured out the cut off time for counting a puzzle as part of a streak? I'm getting back into solving every day after taking a break for a few years. The cut off time used to be 3 a.m. ET the morning after a puzzle's "day" (IE the cut off time for a Tuesday puzzle was 3 a.m. Monday), but the time window seems to have expanded since then, and is counted differently on my phone and my laptop. Any theories appreciated!!

Lewis is OK!!!!  Here's his email to me that he's asked me to share with you:

"Hi Nancy,

No damage, but for two days, no power, NO WATER!, no internet, no phone.  Saturday night the power came back on, but all the other things are off.  (I found a wifi place a good distance from home.)  Anyway, I'll let you know when news happens and I'm able to report it.  We're basically doing okay.  The killer is being without water, and it sounds like we'll be without it for at least two weeks.

Anyway, would you be so kind as to let both blogs know that I am okay and anxious to return, and I will when we get wifi once again; don't know how long that will be; it is rightfully lower on the  priority list of needs in the area."

Since the comments about the actual puzzle have yet to begin I would like to share a few late posts from yesterday that many may have missed …they related to rutabagas, the North Shore of Long Island, and a suggestion for those looking to pick up/prepare a nice side-dish for the upcoming Holiday season. See: https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/426tlt?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

I thought 28A could be a theme answer, too.  Look, it's the Little Mermaid...oh, never mind!

AREEL...


!!!

!!!

!!!

For some reason the use of homonyms for the concealed monsters left me a little flat.  I actually caught on to the trick at the first themer and guessed that none of the others would be spelt correctly, so it didn’t slow me down.  What did slow me down a bit by making me get the dreaded “something’s amiss” message was having isayno and ene instead of ISAYSO and ESE, which actually could have been right. It was a perfectly fine puzzle, but just not my cup of tea.
AMOS? The only Amos I know is Tori. (See yesterday haha.)

Agree that homonyms for the theme answers was very underwhelming. I think it’s because usually when there’s something a little off about a puzzle, you learn it’s because of some clever wordplay you missed. In this case, it’s just because the constructor wanted to hide Bigfoot in the puzzle and couldn’t figure out how to do it without fudging his goal. Meh.
This didn’t slow me down because I had the cross already, but YIPES?

Thanks to author of the Cryptid Catcher and the Cryptid Keeper, Lija Fisher, today’s revealer was easy for me. I got nessee thanks to Stephanie Myers of Twilight. So honestly this puzzle read more like a literary fantasy theme. I found it interesting and fun.

What is the point of misspelt monster names embedded in the theme answers? Yes, they sound similar but since they aren’t real words, they aren’t homonyms either. Would’ve been more interesting to embed the correctly spelled names.

Re: 49A

I realize we’re talking imaginary beasts, but there’s no such thing as a YEDI - it’s YETI. So while the puzzle theme is cutesy, the clue for this answer really doesn’t work.
I spent forever flyspecking my mistake. Compass direction could be ESE or ENE, as the cross because I SAY NO works just as well as I SAY SO. Both should be acceptable as it works in both directions.
62A is wrong it’s said 5 times in the chorus not 4 and that really threw me off.
It is absolutely *wild* that the letters matching the shaded and full answers cannot be entered as a rebus (e.g., "CG" for the fifth letter of 35A).

I felt like I got left hanging with the whole homonym angle - I expected the “typos” to be cleverly acknowledged in the revealer. Maybe “cryptypo” zoology? 

Overall a fun Tuesday and I since I got the theme early I had the satisfaction of filling in the themed clues first.

I asked myself “why are the cryptids spelled wrong?” 

a) They are creatures studied by a “crypto crypto zoologist”. I mean, loads of people have seen a Bigfoot, but who has seen a Bicfoot? 
b) It’s a commentary on cryptocurrency, which is, um, faker than fake… 
c) It’s Jeff Chen’s ploy to get us speculating amongst ourselves, while Nessie and friends take over society.

This one fell a little flat for me.  I can't really explain it... the theme answers should have felt zany and fun but they didn't and when I got to SER at 45 down I actually sighed in disappointment lol! 

I think maybe a lot of the cluing felt like straight forward definitions. Yes, looking back it felt more like a crossword quiz than a crossword puzzle.  Ah me.  Anyway, still happy to have spent time solving it :)
Why is Bigfoot spelled Bicfoot?
Assam is in Northeastern India, not northwestern.

28A (AREEL) is familiar to me as a word which Spelling Bee doesn't accept (joining a long list of words which are frequent or at least occasional crossword entries, but verboten as far as Spelling Bee is concerned).  Per Ralph Waldo Emerson, "a foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds," so I've decided to embrace it as a lovable quirk of NYT Games.

It is quite rare than I can enter a spanner without any crosses, but today that was the case. I typed in CRYPTOZOOLOGIST before I actually had any of the themed entries - basing my guess on the clues themselves. I learned the word from the amazing PC game Disco Elysium, a visual and narrative masterpiece with some of the most amazing world-, story- and character-building I have ever experienced.

Before I got that far though my heart sank when I saw the first themed entry was sport-based. Would they all be like that, I thought with despair. Well, no, but... imperial units? Oh dang! In the end though the puzzle was easy enough to complete, if not particularly quickly, for a Tuesday. No lookups needed.

It's just a shame the homophone part of the themed entries had no revealer.
I agree with those that find the themed answers annoying. It's not funny enough to make me like it.
The constructor's "Bicfoot" story is like the Simpsons episode where Chief Wiggum installs Flanders's new toilet next to the refrigerator because it was too heavy to lug upstairs.
I kid you not my first guess for the revealer was Phenomenologist and it fit so I figured it had it right until it wasn't lining up. Go figure

Why is Hurrah spelt as HOORAH, and not HOORAY?

Is that how it is most commonly spelled in the US?
I got YETI/YEDI first, so I thought it was a little quip about a COPYEDITOR at first until I realised they were all spelt funny. Honestly I found it smarter with the first option 😭

Love it. Combines cryptozoology (from kryptos - Greek for hidden; the study of hidden animals) with cryptology (or cryptography; the study of codes -- and how to break them -- i.e. the study of hidden words): hidden animals/hidden words, put 'em together and you have this puzzle! 

That's a laugh, Bill Nye as the true north crowning entry of this grid: he's been a lovely debunker of pseudoscience and promoter of actual science, so I bet he'd grin to find himself enthroned atop a puzzle of cryptid seekers, and Igor, of course, cryptid-adjacent.

Well, off to the gym. We're working with a trainer who usually gives uS A SQUAT CHallenge. Wait! Did I just see a huge dude covered in FUR walk by? Nah...

While I'm out of my hotel room, I hope they make my bed. Wait! Does that woman doing a CIRCUIT in the pool have a fish tail?? Nah, I guess it's the chamBER MAID.
Stumped by ZEE because here, we go by ZED. Otherwise, good one - always happy to see Jeff Chen in the list.
Amazing crossword, but there is one thing. I searched up the Shake it Off lyrics and 'hate' is actually repeated five times, not four. Amazing theme though. Good job!

I don’t really understand… the theme consist of words that contain sections that sound like the creatures? 

Maybe suggesting, people, like CRYPTOZOOLOGISTS, who believe in these creatures, or seek them out, might see them where others don’t? 

If that’s the case, I think the revealer could have been clued differently. 

[Pseudoscientists who might *read more* into four of the clues in this puzzle.]

Anyway. Big Foot is real. Not sure about the rest. Fun Puzzle. Thanks, Kevin Curry -  and thanks, yet again, to the inimitable Jeff Chen.

Agree with most of the comments regarding dissatisfaction with today's puzzle (not to mention some technical issues with NYT site that did not allow me to begin the puzzle until an hour later). 17A followed by 23A made me realize misspelling was intentional. The theme was overall weak and same goes for the clues. Could 45D clue be something like "GoT Title?" instead of "To be, in Spanish"?
What was most annoying was 8D. Never a fan of compass direction clues, this one was among the worst in which two possible answers could make sense, but without the ingenuity of that one particularly memorable crossword that had two possible solutions to every clue.

I thought my friend would listen to the cryptozoology podcast. Yeti doesn't.

(You knew I'd be kraken a joke.)
Is there a place to check out the grids on the monthly puzzles?  I don't recall seeing that.
I found this a very fun puzzle!  I hope to see more puzzles from Curry and Chen!
Elie Levine has all the facts right about Assam including the very real rhino. Except she is looking in the wrong corner of India. It's in northeastern India not northwest

Never has the "Congratulations!" message been less satisfying.

I "finished" the puzzle before I felt ready - the apparently correct answers looked wrong.

Just a lot of work for what felt like a non-sensical theme that was not worth the effort.

But I "solved" it !?!
I still don't understand why the theme words are spelled wrong!  Is it because you just think you see them but they're not really there?
Loved this puzzle! Theme was cute, and fun. Perfect for a Tuesday.

i also thought the premise didn't cohere well, BUT "cryptozoologist" does tie things together if one thinks of "crypto" as referring to names that need deciphering. I must commend the writer below on the "crypto-typo" idea!
Congrats to Chan and Carry - oops, not quite right (similar to this puzzle.)
The monsters’ names are just spelt wrong. Doesn’t make sense.

“Rather than running through the clues in order, I start by filling in what I know.”

I don’t get this. How do you know anything without running through the clues?

Do people actually just look at the grid and know the answers without reading any clues?

And if not, then are you trying to say that you just read the clues randomly and not in any order? (“Hey, let’s try 25D. Why not?”)
Random typos in the theme words?  I think "I guess they couldn't bother to make it work" NOT "Clever twist."

I thoroughly enjoyed today's puzzle! Thought the theme was very clever--after all isn't the defining feature of cryptids that we're never quite sure if we really saw them? Hence, the "typos" hidden within the larger words!
I was perplexed by the misspellings, but overjoyed to see my alma mater show up. A little love for WASHU, the Harvard of the Midwest (or so they said when I was applying back in 1989). Go Bears!
The simplest fix to the frustrating spelling mistakes in the cryptids would be for the clue to be for "siteings", that way you'd connect the spelling mistake with the four answers.
Fun puzzle except for the words being spelled wrong. That seems like cheating on the construction to me.

Ah, the legendary CUBICFOOT. This is a European species closely related to another high-mountain dweller, the Dahu. We have many of these noble animals in my part of Switzerland. They are quadrupeds who have evolved with two legs on one side of the body shorter than those on the opposite side. This asymmetry allows it to move in great comfort around a mountain. Unfortunately, only in one direction. Hence, two types of dahu exist, the laevogyrous, or lefty, dahu and the dextrogyre, the righty. I believe, in a prehistoric evolutionary sense, they are also closely related to an American bird, the snipe, and are hunted with much the same technique. This evolutionary correlation between bird and animal can also be observed in my own favorite pet, the emu.
For those of you interested in adopting a specimen of one or another of these wondrous species, I highly recommend the excellent Fiona Bowron’s « How to Keep a Werewolf: And Other Exotic Pets Which May or May Not a) Exist or b) Eat You. » 
Wondrous puzzle. My cryptid and I thank the constructors heartily.

Ah, the legendary CUBICFOOT. This is a European species closely related to another high-mountain dweller, the Dahu. We have many of these noble animals in my part of Switzerland. They are quadrupeds who have evolved with two legs on one side of the body shorter than those on the opposite side. This asymmetry allows it to move in great comfort around a mountain. Unfortunately, only in one direction. Hence, two types of dahu exist, the laevogyrous, or lefty, dahu and the dextrogyre, the righty. I believe, in a prehistoric evolutionary sense, they are also closely related to an American bird, the snipe, and are hunted with much the same technique. This evolutionary correlation between bird and animal can also be observed in my own favorite pet, the emu.
For those of you interested in adopting a specimen of one or another of these wondrous species, I highly recommend the excellent Fiona Bowron’s « How to Keep a Werewolf: And Other Exotic Pets Which May or May Not a) Exist or b) Eat You. » 
Wondrous puzzle. My cryptid and I thank the constructors heartily.

I immediately plugged in CRYPTOZOOLOGIST when I saw the revealer clue, but when I started getting the theme clues and saw they were misspelled, I was sure I’d have to revisit that and change it to CRTYPOZOOLOGIST to acknowledge they were typos. I was surprised when the victory music played when I entered my last letter without going back to that. 

Upon reflection, it’s obvious that the joke is meant to be pseudoscientists seeing things that aren’t really there. The scare quotes around “sightings” should have made that clear to me. Now that I understand the theme, I like it. 

However, a minor edit for clarity to something like “false sightings” or “disputed sightings” would have made the theme much more legible and probably avoided all the comment section grumbling.

I seem to be the only one so far who struggled with this; it felt far harder than the average Tuesday, spelling issues aside. I’m putting it down to struggling with a nasty head cold. My skull is full of cotton wool so definitely not firing on all cylinders.
The theme was ok. I get it but it didn’t set my world on fire. Ah well, off to steam my head again.

Came here to see if others were perplexed by the homonyms, was not disappointed. 

I think what bothers me most is the Jeff Chin pointing out the homonyms without mentioning why. I mean, there are lots of guesses, but he could clear things up in a flash. 

Absolutely great puzzle otherwise.

I loved the puzzle. Despite what others might say, the homonyms make sense in that a cryptozoologist looks for something they is there but actually doesn't exist, like the words might appear to be the mythical creature but actually aren't. Hiding in plain sight!

Well done!

2 years of (89% of the time) completing the crossword. 
After 1 year, I had yet to complete a Friday or Saturday without lookups. So I set myself 10 goals for year 2.
1-7: Bring average daily times below a certain time, personal to me - all achieved
8-9: Complete a Friday and a Saturday with no look-ups - achieved. Maybe not as often as I would like, but that's ok. Some weeks I can fly a Friday and get nowhere on Saturday. Next week can be the opposite. It is getting easier though, I think!
10: Construct a crossword - far from achieved, but attempted at least. Grid design is a complete bafflement to me. Kudos to all who do

Goal for year 3: Continue to enjoy :)

YIPES!  Not a lot of love in the comments today.  

I thought it was a cute idea.  Just like the person who used to cut my husbands hair who frequently thought she saw BIg(G) FOOT at her camp (and had photos to "prove" it), you could read CUBIC FOOT and think you saw BIg FOOT.  It worked for me.

That was different. Solved this in a normal Tuesday time and caught on to the 'trick' but can't say that I entirely understood it. Apparently I'm not alone. No big deal - still an enjoyable solve for the most part. Unusual puzzle find today. A Saturday from April 1(!), 2000 by Manny Nosowsky. Some sample clues/answers: "Torment." - TTTT "Some socials." - TTTT "Golfers needs." - TTTTT "Flirt" - TTTTT And so on and so forth. Altogether there were twelve T's answers, each of them on the very edge of the puzzle, across and down. Don't recall seeing one like that before. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/1/2000 I'm done. ..

I liked this one! Having some interest in the paranormal & cryptids made this puzzle fun for me and if Jeff or Kevin reads these, just wanted you to know the idea landed with at least a few people. 

While I absolutely understand others disappointment in the theme entries, it made total sense to me - as the creatures are hiding in plain sight within the puzzle, and can only be seen (heard) if you're specifically looking for them and hoping to find them. Just like the "real" ones.

Re: 15A x 8D ambiguity

[Because] I SAY SO 
is a much more 
common expression than 
[Because] I SAY nO,
but the crossword
often does not use
the more common case.

Easy fix: 
change the clue 
for ESE from 
[Compass heading] to
[Language suffix].
Hated it. The intentional misspellings of the beasts was unfair, and Frankenstein's assistant was Fritz, not Igor.

After scanning the comments: 

Thank you Nancy/NYC for the update on Lewis/Ashville NC.  Glad to hear he and his family are safe. 

Excellent fixes suggested for 

The revealer:  CRYPTYPOZOOLOGY

The clue: [Pseudoscientist investigating "siteings" . . .]
Fun puzzle, but the misspellings were pointless.

Wait, we're supposed to believe that BICFOOT sounds like bigfoot and so forth? I don't buy it. Possibly more accurate just to say that for each clue the hunter almost, but not quite, saw the thing s/he was looking for. Nevertheless, I got all the themers pretty easily.

What messed me up until I went back and found the error was that I confidently entered CRYPTObiOLOGIST for the person who studies imaginary animals, so I didn't get the music until I found the -ZO- where it belonged.

Unlike many, I think I kinda like the theme. If you take the “word-recognition” approach, rather than “phonetics” (which, yes, yields that excellent cryptotypo… pun which others have noted), then these blurry images of things that don’t really exist sort of jump off the page.

Apologies that this explanation tended to drag on.
For real!

Sorry, I didn't like this theme.  Purposeful and outright misspellings under the guise of them being "cryptic" seems fake, phony, and also lazy.

The ham-handed workers clue was fun though.

Now to read the comments.  ;)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)

Disappointed in this theme. I was able to figure out the monsters pretty quickly and filled them all in, only to be then stuck debugging for 10 mins: what is a cubig foot ??? 

A cute idea but poor execution. 
I don't think the etidors should have let this one slide... sigh.
Filled in the whole grid, only to find I had an error somewhere… who spells it as HOORAH?? Never knew there was a portmanteau of “hooray” (which I had) and “hurrah”.

I thought this theme was really clever.   I didn't really think of them as homonyms (mucKRAKINg not pronounced the same as Kraken) - just that the words were false sightings, typical of cryptozoologists:

I see Bigfoot!  Nope - it was just something resembling Bigfoot but actually explained by something else.

I just wanted to confirm for the one about Taylor Swift's song, all the repeating words are repeated AT LEAST FIVE times. So, I don't get why it is HATE. Afterwards, I did refer to the lyrics, which were really FIVE TIMES.

Clever and fun theme, but not a Tuesday level puzzle for me.  No surprise, as I am finding this the case more often than not.  At least I didn’t have to turn on Auto correct. 

Always nice to see Jeff’s name.

My reactions solving-

Nice! An early-week that requires some effort! 
HOORAH!

Wait…that’s not how it’s spelled…

Uhh..that’s *obviously* not how it’s spelled…

Is there a rebus I’m missing? Not sure I like this one…

Finished, got the gold star.

Went back to look and realized

I was *seeing*things that weren’t actually there!!

Yay!

Mispelings fer tha winn!

Ah, thank goodness for the commentariat. I was pretty annoyed with this one until I read other puzzlers' explanations: The theme clues are not homonyms as much as false sightings. 

The qualifying language in each theme clue and then the scare quotes around [sightings] in the revealer all point to it, but I didn't get it (at all) until I came here. 

Not sure if that makes the revealers insufficient, the puzzle extra clever, or me extra slow! Whichever way, this was for me a puzzle enjoyed primarily after the fact.
Bicfoot? Whaa?

I loved the puzzle but then again I always love the ones I can complete with a gold star. Really though, I think it was a fun theme, and the clues in parentheses really helped, although I do understand the commenters who take issue with the misspellings.

Hmm.  No Reveal, but obviously a bit of a trick.  The "substitutions" don't spell anything.  Maybe it's meant to be like this (I thought to myself)--if you have very sloppy enunciation.

CRYPTO, for sure.

PARSLEY before PINE NUT (only one?  Geez Louise!  Scrooge!)

Who says WASH U?  Or AREEL?
I sort of like this puzzle, being a fan of NESSIE (and of OPOSSUMs,) but I really do not like being forced to misspell anything, and while I don't HATE Taylor Swift, I have never listened to any of her music/songs.  "Napoleon Dynamite" also falls into the Meh Category.  

C Plus.  Points off for spelling.  
Don't PAWN your soul for publication.

I thought one letter of each shaded area should have a substitution and the letters substituted would form a revealer. Unscrambled I get egit (or is it iget?) which might make sense in Pig Latin (or some kid language my brother used to insult me) as idiot, what I felt like at the end.  

But honestly I really like this puzzle.
What fun! Congrats Kevin Curry for a wonderfully wacky Tuesday grid. Great clues and fill throughout. Thrilled to see Jeff Chen again. You are missed!

Nessie is of course alive and well, and visitors are welcome to come and see her frolicking in the loch. There's a charge of course, for the hire of the special binoculars you need to see her properly. Available from street vendors in Inverness and Fort Augustus. Nessie is a problem for the endangered wild haggis which inhabit the woods on the quieter south-east shore.

What is this LDEASTS of which you speak??? (Only kidding!)

So many people not getting the theme...

It seemed pretty obvious to me, and super cute. They're false sightings, that's why they're spelled wrong. The idea of a hairy monster with cigarette lighters for feet cracked me up. "No no, that's BICFOOT. He's not mysterious at all."

I honestly can’t decide if I love or HATE this puzzle. I love the theme idea of hidden mythical creatures inside other answers, and I understand the CRYPTO connection (I agree with others that “questioning what you’re seeing” is a better explanation over homonyms), but I just don’t like puzzles with misspellings. Should I get over it? Probably, since the editors seem intent on accepting such puzzles a few times a year.

Personally, I think this would have been easier to swallow as an easy Thursday puzzle.

Has anyone else's NYT app changed? My Android app format has totally rearranged, and some previous, valued functions are now gone. For example, I used to be able to access the Wordplay column from a button in the Games tab that said "Read about today's crossword." Now I have to manually search for the column -- it'snot linked anywhere in Games. I also used to be able to see my Crossword streak (250  days!) under the Games tab, and my completed puzzles and puzzle times. None are now visible. However, many of us in the NYTXW community track our streaks, puzzle completion times, and other puzzle info. Please make this all visible again in the Games tab in the NYT app. And please continue to link the Wordplay column to the daily crossword. Otherwise, to me, this app redesign is a major downgrade -- my daily use has been made harder and more annoying. Does anyone from Wordplay have any more information about this redesign? Could these issues please be fixed?

Interesting theme execution! I found the homonyms quite hard to suss out while solving even after solving the first one as I think my brain is just not good at searching for homonyms. It was some good mental discomfort for a Tuesday while keeping the overall solve time in line with expectations.

A copy editor isn't a professional proofreader. I know because I was a professional proofreader once upon a time. 

I was lukewarm about the theme until I read the comments that made me realize we're all "seeing things" in this puzzle. A visual pun makes more sense than misspelled homophones, and is much funnier.

I loved this one! I'm still relatively new to crosswords and this was a no-lookup-Tuesday for me! I'm always pumped when I can achieve that :)

I thought the theme was super cute
This was a lot of fun. I got the revealer before I finished the themed clues, but I still needed an ahha moment to "see" the shaded squares! Not difficult, but it made me smile.
I’d like to vent about Vertex being dropped.

Ah, the power of wishful thinking. You see bicfoot and want to believe you've seen BigFoot.

This was a fun one, thanks Kevin and Jeff.

Helene left me without power for 3 days and without internet for another day past that. No AC, no coffee in the morning, lots of tree branches down, lost some roof shingles, lost all the food in fridge. But blessedly, no lights ruining the night sky. Exceedingly fortunate that we only caught the edge of that storm. Some tornado damage in the county, but not the disastrous conditions that most of Georgia  suffered.

OMG, they're ALL spelled wrong!!!!!

What a dummy I am!  I was so flummoxed by BICFOOT, couldn't replace that C with a G no matter how hard I tried, so I came here to see what Rex had said about it.  Was there perhaps an alternate spelling of BIGFOOT?

Yes, I had noticed NESSEE, not NESSIE -- and was going to complain that they'd chosen a "less familiar and less accepted" spelling.  It never occurred to me that NESSEE wasn't a spelling at all.

KRAKIN and YEDI sort of sailed right over my head.

Did I pick up on the deliberateness of the misspellings when I saw the word  "pseudoscientist" along with "sightings" in quotation marks in the revealer clue?  Ah, but that would have taken something resembling actual intelligence and Today I Am An Idiot.

This puzzle has it all:  Enormous originality, terrific humor, and for me, a much-too-long-delayed "Aha Moment" that blew me away.  An irresistible candidate for Puzzle-of-the-Year.

Absolutely baffled by most of the Reader's Picks comments for this puzzle. I thoroughly enjoyed it and thought it was incredibly well-constructed. It was fun filling in the shaded portions, then realizing they were purposefully misspelled. The [SIC] and COPYEDITOR in the southwest quadrant especially felt cleverly cheeky. One of my favorite puzzles in my 3  years of completing NYT Crosswords!
Tried several times to fit TYPO into the revealer at 57A to no avail… still seems like a shoo-in, but maybe too gimmicky.
I kept waiting to see the JERSEY DEBIL appear, from out of the Pine Barrens. Left disappointed.

Am I the first one to point out that a homoNYM is a word that shares a spelling but differs in meaning, whereas a homoPHONE is what we're actually talking about with this puzzle?

To be very clear: this puzzle contained homophones of cryptids, not homonyms.

("Phone" is the root for "sound" and "nym" is the root for "name.")

Late puzzle find. Don't recall seeing one like this before - thought it was quite clever. Anyway... a Saturday from September 30, 1995 by Bryan White. Three theme answers in that one. Here are the clues and answers: "Magi? :" THEYYYMEN "Arctic or Indian, e.g.? :" ONEOFTHECCCCCCC "When flower children bloomed? :" THETTTTTT Took me a moment to catch on. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/30/1995&g=62&d=A ...
Can I just go on record stating that I hate puzzles where multiple characters must be entered in some squares and the puzzle solver has to guess the arbitrary syntax that will be deemed "correct"?

It happens sometimes that I don't get the theme until after the puzzle is done.  When that happens, I'll spend some time after the solving to figure it out.  Sometimes this results in a lovely "a-ha" moment; sometimes merely an "is that all?"

That didn't happen today.  I figured out today's theme about two-thirds of the way through solving, and I thought it was quite clever.

All this is a preface to the surprisingly large number of commenters who didn't get the theme, apparently didn't try too hard to figure it out, and then announced their lack of understanding to the community.  Do they not realize that this makes them look...not terribly intelligent?
Loved the theme today, I'm a big cryptid-head and I was delighted when I saw the silly play on them coming together. Well done!
Meh. Homonyms.  I’m a big fan of Jeff Chen. This is not one of my favorites.
Great Tuesday, loved it.

With apologies - one more late puzzle find. This is the only one I've ever encountered that I simply do not grasp the trick at all. Maybe somebody can explain it. Anyway - a Sunday from September 10, 1989 by Bert H. Kruse with the title: "Weekly tabloid editor's dreams." Some theme clue/answer examples: "Precocious Ivy Leaguer! :" YALEGRADATTWO "Concorde bows to big birds! :" GEESEBEATSST "Paris art palace lifted! :" LOUVRESTOLEN "Great Lake being emptied! :" DRAINHURON I'm just not seeing what those theme answers are supposed to be referencing. Maybe somebody can explain. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=9/10/1989&g=87&d=A ..

Not to be too technical, but doesn't Taylor Swift repeat HATE five times (not four) in the chorus of "Shake It Off"? 

I feel weird to be the one to point this out considering I would never call myself a Swiftie... but I found myself confused when I was singing through the chorus and kept counting five HATEs on my fingers lol

I think the controversy around this one boils down to one thing:

If you didn't like it, the theme was "misspelled" names of legendary creatures.

If you did like it, the theme was *correctly* spelled things that have, hidden in them, spellings of legendary creatures, but off by one letter.  AND, that the theme poked fun of these sightings.

I gotta tell you, I've gone from being underwhelmed to thinking this may be the most subtle and witty puzzle I've ever seen.

The more I consider this, the more I consider it a really interesting and witty effort at parodying those stupid sightings.

Of course, Barry Ancona will disagree, but the intentional misspelling of cryptids because it makes the full possible is lame. 

Making it less lame would be a clue explaining that the "Cryptozoologist" (<- spelled correctly in the grid, which is also inconsistent with the other answers brings homonyms) was a bad speller.  

If only there was an answer like "Sic" in the grid that could be used to tie it all together (Of course, there was but the clue was a dud).  

P.S. Jeff Chen is overrated.

@Eric Hougland 

Precisely because the clue didn't reference any geography, I knew the comment must have referred to the column -- even though I didn't read this one. 

The lack of copy editing shows over and over in the Wordplay column, and it gets annoying. Of course this is a staffing and budgeting issue, not really the fault of the columnists. But given that is the world we live in, IMO more care should be given. 

Hey, if you're not certain about a fact you're writing, which will be viewed worldwide, perhaps take a moment and look it up. 

(Not to mention, taking that moment for a sanity check might make one realize that silk production likely takes place in a region near other silk-producing counties -- all to the east. An educated guess, at minimum.)

@G 

My husband is a smart guy, but he has trouble sometimes distinguishing left from right. I like to think that I’m smart too, but I sometimes get confused by the “No left turn” signs that are only an arrow with a slash through it. 

So maybe Elie Levine took a quick look at the map and moved Assam to the wrong side of the country. Maybe in her head she was typing “east” and it came out “west.” Maybe autocorrect helpfully intervened. 

We have no way of knowing. What we do know is that if the NYT employed sufficient editors, this error probably would have been caught. 

Errors in the Wordplay column are concerning, but I would personally prefer that the NYT focus its editorial efforts on its new reporting.

As I said in another thread, I used to have editors and proofreaders who scrutinized everything I wrote. They saved me from embarrassment more time than I can remember. (I’ve even forgiven them for the school district fiscal year contretemps.)

@Desert Dweller 

I'd like to second what Heathie said.

And I'd like to add that this:  

I never have a problem with constructive criticism.  But I do have a problem with disdainful and belittling comments concerning the people who made the puzzle, in particular the constructor.

I've never attempted to construct a crossword, and I never will because it looks to be a gigantic undertaking.  Many of the commenters here *have* constructed puzzles, and as I've learned that I've grown to understand their perspective more.

But they are exclusively are in the constructive criticism business.

This is more like a high school play than professional football.  I'd don't have any real problems criticizing someone for their performance when they're being paid like princes to do it.

But the constructors here do it almost entirely out of love of the craft.  They get paid a pittance.  If they were paid even remotely minimum wage, the puzzles section would be ten times as expensive.  Maybe more.

I tend to defend the constructors for this reason.  As Heathie said you're free to like or not like a puzzle, and comment on it thusly.  

However, when you post a comment, you, too, are performing, in a way, and you, too, are going to be subject to criticism.  We have the right to not like your opinion.  Hell, we even have the right to "rebuke" you, although I don't see it that way, and I don't think most of us do.  (I'm probably the worst, and I really don't think I'm all that bad.
